_header: When folk had laughen at this nice cas
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Reeve’s Prologue of the Canterbury Tales — 66 lines in couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
Whan folk had laughwen at this nyce casof Absolon & hende
                    Nicholas…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…he can wel in myn yghe seen a stalkebut in his owne he can
                    nought seen a balke
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And next folwith the Revis prolog (f. 57v); the Revis
                    prolog (RT); Here endith the Revis prolog… (f. 58)

BodBar20.First Lines:
When folke han laughen at þis nyce casOf Absalon and hende
                    Nicholas…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…He con wel in myn Eye Seen a stalkeBut in his owen he con not
                    se a balke
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
…and / here by gynnyth þe prologe of þe / Reves tale (f.
                    43); The Reve (RT); here endith þe prologe of þe Reves tale… (f.
                    44)

CULGg427.First Lines:

                    lyf & let it gon…

                    not sen a balke
